normalised: Five G rollout gains momentum across India

unnormalised: New Delhi – The nationwide rollout of 5G services continues to accelerate, with major telecom operators Jio and Airtel expanding their networks across key metropolitan areas and Tier II cities. This expansion includes significant infrastructure upgrades in regions like Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu, and Uttar Pradesh.
normalised: New Delhi – The nationwide rollout of five G services continues to accelerate, with major telecom operators Jio and Airtel expanding their networks across key metropolitan areas and Tier two cities. This expansion includes significant infrastructure upgrades in regions like Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu, and Uttar Pradesh.

unnormalised: Reliance Jio announced further investment, exceeding Rs. 20,000 crore, dedicated to expanding 5G infrastructure, specifically targeting underserved rural districts, echoing the government's BharatNet initiative.
normalised: Reliance Jio announced further investment, exceeding rupee twenty thousand crore, dedicated to expanding five G infrastructure, specifically targeting underserved rural districts, echoing the government's BharatNet initiative.

unnormalised: Airtel also reported significant progress, achieving speeds of over 1 Gbps in select locations. The Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) is actively monitoring network performance and spectrum allocation to ensure fair competition and optimal service delivery.
normalised: Airtel also reported significant progress, achieving speeds of over one gigabits per second in select locations. The Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (T R A I) is actively monitoring network performance and spectrum allocation to ensure fair competition and optimal service delivery.

unnormalised: The Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Madras is collaborating with several telecom companies to develop indigenous 5G solutions. The potential benefits of this technology extend beyond enhanced connectivity, promising significant advancements in sectors like healthcare, agriculture, and manufacturing.
normalised: The Indian Institute of Technology (I I T) Madras is collaborating with several telecom companies to develop indigenous five G solutions. The potential benefits of this technology extend beyond enhanced connectivity, promising significant advancements in sectors like healthcare, agriculture, and manufacturing.

unnormalised: Analysts predict that widespread 5G availability will boost India's digital economy, empowering citizens and businesses alike, ushering in a "Rocket Singh: Salesman of the Year"-esque era of technological progress.
normalised: Analysts predict that widespread five G availability will boost India's digital economy, empowering citizens and businesses alike, ushering in a "Rocket Singh: Salesman of the Year"-esque era of technological progress.
